awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Formation and Separation of Nanoscale Contacts
awd_abstract_narration:
As the size of electronic devices shrinks to the nanometer scale, new technologies are required to manufacture and characterize them. Many of these new approaches rely on a nano-sized stylus selectively making contact with a surface, and then modifying or measuring the contacted region. The function, reliability, and precision of these techniques are determined by the properties of the contact, especially the adhesion force, the area of contact, and the deformation of the underlying material. This award supports fundamental research to understand the physics, chemistry, and materials science that govern the formation and separation of contacts at these length scales. The new insights into nanoscale contacts will guide the optimization of existing techniques and the development of novel approaches, helping to keep the U.S. at the forefront of advanced manufacturing and technology. The investigation is being conducted by an interdisciplinary team of researchers, and incorporates specific programs to include participation by people from underrepresented groups. 

Nanocontact behavior will be investigated for chemically and structurally diverse materials, with scientific and technological relevance. Nanocontact experiments will be conducted with in situ transmission electron microscopy that will provide nanonewton force resolution and Angstrom-scale structural information. The experiments will be complemented by molecular dynamics simulations of the same nanocontacts that provide atomic-scale detail about phenomena occurring within the materials and inside the perimeter of the contact, which cannot be viewed directly in experiment. These techniques will be used to characterize adhesion, deformation under load, and load-dependent contact area for a variety of contacts. Taken together, the data will enable evaluation of competing hypotheses that describe nanoscale contact. These insights will have direct impact on probe-based nanomanufacturing and on probe-based microscopy, both of which require precise understanding and control of the tip/sample contact. More generally, the in situ nanoscale testing in this program will yield insights that are relevant to larger-scale applications in which interfaces between materials consist of many nanoscale asperity contacts.

por.por_cntn:
As the size of electronic devices shrinks to the nanometer scale, new technologies are required to manufacture and characterize them. Many of these new approaches rely on a nano-size stylus selectively making contact with a surface and then modifying or measuring the contacted region. The function, reliability, and precision of these techniques are determined by the properties of the contact – especially the adhesion force, the area of contact, and the deformation of the underlying material. The common approach to predicting these properties is calculation using simple equations that were developed for contact at larger length scales. However, such theories may no longer be accurate for nano-size contacts. This project used simulations and experiments to explore how contacts form, evolve, and break to test the applicability of traditional theories to contact at the nanoscale.

The key findings of this project include the following. First, metal nanocontacts composed of platinum behave very differently from the predictions of conventional models. The size of the contact spot, even at the lightest possible loads, is much larger than previously thought. This results from crystal defects that arise during contact, but are removed when the contact is broken so they cannot be detected afterwards. Second, when electrical current is passed through platinum contacts, the conduction is far smaller than classical model predictions. This is attributed to atomic-scale surface layers that cannot be easily removed. Third, for technologically-relevant silicon contacts, contact behavior depends strongly on how much force is applied. While prior investigations focused on adhesive loads, this project provided conclusive evidence that, when load is applied to a contact, there are significant changes in how strongly the contact adheres and how much it deforms. Fourth, overall, this project has shed light on the very definition of what it means to be “in contact” at the nanoscale. The results showed that different techniques for measuring contact size can result in very different values. The findings also showed that the predictions of commonly applied models for nanoscale contact often deviate significantly from the true behavior, and suggested corrections to improve their applicability to real-world contacts. Taken together, these advances move the field closer to being able to describe and predict the sometimes surprising behavior that occurs when nanoscale materials come into contact.

From a technological perspective, this research has direct impact on probe-based nanomanufacturing and on probe-based microscopy – both of which require precise understanding and control of the tip/sample contact. More generally, the findings are relevant to larger-scale applications in which interfaces between materials consist of many nanoscale contact spots. The research in this project was coupled with education and outreach activities, including involvement of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in the research as well as engagement with students from elementary to high school, all with the aim of broadening participation in science and engineering.
